conclusion: Two objects start from the same location and move in the same direction; need to find when they meet again.
Objects meet when their positions are equal, meaning they have covered the same distance.
Velocity-time graph shows how fast each object is moving; area under curve represents distance traveled.
Graph has time on x-axis and velocity on y-axis with curves labeled A and B.
Object A starts with high velocity and decreases over time, reaching zero at t2.
Object B starts with low velocity, increases to a peak, then decreases.
Marked points on graph: t1, t2, t3, t4.
Both curves above time axis, meaning both objects move in positive direction.
At t1, curve A crosses horizontal axis, velocity becomes zero.
At t2, object B reaches peak velocity.
Need to focus on areas under curves to find when objects meet.
From t=0 to t=t1, object A's velocity decreases to zero; object B's velocity increases.
From t=t1 to t=t2, object A's velocity is zero; object B continues moving.
From t=t2 to t=t4, object A's velocity increases; object B's velocity decreases.
Consider positions as integrals of velocities over time.
Objects meet when integral of velocity A equals integral of velocity B.
At t1, object A has covered some distance; object B has covered less.
At t2, object A is stationary; object B may have caught up.
Between t1 and t2, object B closes the gap as object A is stationary.
At t2, check if areas under curves are equal.
At t3, curves intersect, meaning velocities are equal.
Equal velocities at t3 don't mean equal distances covered.
Up to t3, object B has covered more distance than object A.
